subject: Physics
title: Mass Density
description: Definition of density. \(\rho\): mass density [kg/m^3], \(m\): mass [kg], \(V\): volume [m^3].
derivation:
Density is a fundamental property defined as mass per unit volume.
Consider a homogeneous substance sample.
If we take a sample of mass \(m\) and volume \(V\), the ratio is constant:
\(\rho = m / V\)

related_concepts.name: Homogeneous Material
related_concepts.definition: A material that has the same uniform properties and composition throughout.

related_concepts.name: Specific Volume
related_concepts.definition: The inverse of density, defined as volume per unit mass (\(v = 1/\rho\)).

subject: Physics
title: Specific Gravity
description: Relative density. \(SG\): Specific Gravity [unitless], \(\rho_{\text{water}}\): density of water at 4^\circ C.
derivation:
Specific Gravity compares the density of a substance to a reference.
Usually, the reference is water for liquids.
It is a dimensionless ratio of two densities:
\(SG = \frac{\rho_{sub}}{\rho_{ref}}\)

related_concepts.name: Reference Density
related_concepts.definition: The standard density used for comparison, usually water at 4°C (1000 kg/m³) for liquids.

subject: Physics
title: Hydrostatic Pressure
description: Pressure at depth. \(P\): absolute pressure, \(P_0\): atmospheric pressure, \(h\): depth.
derivation:
Consider a fluid column of height \(h\) and area \(A\).
The forces acting on the fluid column are gravity and pressure.
1. Downward force from air: \(F_{top} = P_0 A\)
2. Weight of the fluid: \(W = mg = (\rho V)g = \rho (Ah) g\)
3. Upward force from fluid below: \(F_{bottom} = P A\)
Since the fluid is static, forces balance: \(F_{bottom} = F_{top} + W\)
\(PA = P_0 A + \rho A h g\)
Dividing by \(A\) gives:
\(P = P_0 + \rho g h\)

related_concepts.name: Gauge Pressure
related_concepts.definition: The pressure relative to atmospheric pressure (\(P_{gauge} = \rho g h\)).

related_concepts.name: Absolute Pressure
related_concepts.definition: The total pressure, including atmospheric pressure.

subject: Physics
title: Pascal's Law
description: Transmission of pressure in an enclosed fluid.
derivation:
Pascal's Law states that pressure change is transmitted undiminished.
Therefore, pressure at piston 1 equals pressure at piston 2:
\(P_1 = P_2\)
Substituting the definition of pressure \(P = F/A\):
\(\frac{F_1}{A_1} = \frac{F_2}{A_2}\)
This implies a small force on a small area creates a large force on a large area.

related_concepts.name: Mechanical Advantage
related_concepts.definition: The factor by which a force is multiplied. In a hydraulic lift, \(MA = A_2 / A_1\).

subject: Physics
title: Buoyant Force
description: Upward buoyant force on a submerged object.
derivation:
Pressure increases with depth, creating a net upward force.
Force at bottom (depth \(h_2\)): \(F_{up} = P_2 A = \rho g h_2 A\)
Force at top (depth \(h_1\)): \(F_{down} = P_1 A = \rho g h_1 A\)
Net Force \(F_B = F_{up} - F_{down} = \rho g A (h_2 - h_1)\)
Since \(A(h_2 - h_1)\) is the Volume \(V\):
\(F_B = \rho g V\)

related_concepts.name: Archimedes' Principle
related_concepts.definition: Any object, wholly or partially immersed in a fluid, is buoyed up by a force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced.

subject: Physics
title: Equation of Continuity
description: Conservation of mass for incompressible flow.
derivation:
Mass flow rate \(\frac{dm}{dt}\) must be constant in a tube of flow.
\(\frac{dm}{dt} = \rho A v\)
For an incompressible fluid, density \(\rho\) is constant.
Therefore, \(\rho A_1 v_1 = \rho A_2 v_2\)
Canceling \(\rho\) gives:
\(A_1 v_1 = A_2 v_2\)

related_concepts.name: Incompressible Flow
related_concepts.definition: Fluid flow where the density remains constant throughout.

related_concepts.name: Volume Flow Rate
related_concepts.definition: The volume of fluid passing a point per unit time (\(Q = Av\)).

subject: Physics
title: Bernoulli's Equation
description: Energy conservation per unit volume.
derivation:
This comes from the Work-Energy theorem on a fluid element.
Work done by pressure forces = Change in Kinetic + Potential Energy.
\(W_{net} = \Delta K + \Delta U\)
Rearranging terms for unit volume:
Pressure Energy + Kinetic Energy + Potential Energy = Constant
\(P + \frac{1}{2}\rho v^2 + \rho g h = \text{constant}\)

related_concepts.name: Dynamic Pressure
related_concepts.definition: The kinetic energy per unit volume of a fluid particle (\(\frac{1}{2}\rho v^2\)).

related_concepts.name: Static Pressure
related_concepts.definition: The actual thermodynamic pressure of the fluid as it flows.

subject: Physics
title: Torricelli's Law
description: Efflux speed from an open tank.
derivation:
Apply Bernoulli's equation between the top surface (1) and the hole (2).
1. Top surface: \(P_1 = P_{atm}\), \(v_1 \approx 0\) (large tank)
2. Hole: \(P_2 = P_{atm}\), height drop is \(h\)
Equation: \(P_{atm} + \rho g h = P_{atm} + \frac{1}{2}\rho v^2\)
\(\rho g h = \frac{1}{2}\rho v^2\)
Solving for \(v\):
\(v = \sqrt{2gh}\)

related_concepts.name: Efflux
related_concepts.definition: The outflow of a fluid from a vessel or pipe.

subject: Physics
title: Stokes' Law
description: Drag on a sphere in laminar flow.
derivation:
Derived for low Reynolds numbers (Laminar Flow).
It assumes the fluid is continuous and the sphere is smooth.
The drag force is proportional to viscosity \(\eta\), radius \(r\), and velocity \(v\).
Detailed derivation requires solving Navier-Stokes equations for creeping flow.
Result:
\(F_d = 6\pi \eta r v\)

related_concepts.name: Viscosity
related_concepts.definition: A measure of a fluid's resistance to deformation or flow (internal friction).

related_concepts.name: Laminar Flow
related_concepts.definition: Smooth flow where fluid particles move in parallel layers.

subject: Physics
title: Terminal Velocity
description: Max falling speed.
derivation:
At terminal velocity, the net force is zero (Equilibrium).
Forces: Weight (Down) = Buoyant (Up) + Drag (Up)
\(mg = F_B + F_d\)
Substitute formulas:
\(\rho_s V g = \rho_f V g + 6\pi \eta r v_t\)
Using \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) and rearranging for \(v_t\):
\(v_t = \frac{2r^2(\rho_s - \rho_f)g}{9\eta}\)

related_concepts.name: Equilibrium
related_concepts.definition: The state where all forces acting on an object are balanced.

subject: Physics
title: Capillary Rise
description: Height of liquid column in a thin tube.
derivation:
Forces balance at the liquid meniscus contact line.
1. Upward force due to surface tension: \(F_{up} = S(2\pi r) \cos \theta\)
2. Downward weight of liquid column: \(W = mg = \rho (\pi r^2 h) g\)
Equating \(F_{up} = W\):
\(S(2\pi r) \cos \theta = \rho \pi r^2 h g\)
Solving for \(h\):
\(h = \frac{2S \cos \theta}{\rho g r}\)

related_concepts.name: Surface Tension
related_concepts.definition: The tendency of liquid surfaces to shrink into the minimum surface area possible.

related_concepts.name: Contact Angle
related_concepts.definition: The angle where a liquid-vapor interface meets a solid surface.

subject: Physics
title: Excess Pressure (Soap Bubble)
description: Pressure difference inside a soap bubble. \(S\): surface tension, \(R\): radius of the bubble (has 2 surfaces).
derivation:
A soap bubble has two surfaces (inner and outer).
The force due to excess pressure pushes outward: \(F_P = \Delta P \cdot \pi R^2\)
The force due to surface tension pulls inward along the circumference (twice): \(F_S = S \cdot 2\pi R \times 2 = 4\pi R S\)
At equilibrium, \(F_P = F_S\):
\(\Delta P \cdot \pi R^2 = 4\pi R S\)
\(\Delta P = \frac{4S}{R}\)

related_concepts.name: Surface Tension
related_concepts.definition: The elastic tendency of a fluid surface which makes it acquire the least surface area possible.

related_concepts.name: Liquid Drop Pressure
related_concepts.definition: For a solid liquid drop (one surface), excess pressure is \(\Delta P = 2S/R\).

subject: Physics
title: Reynolds Number
description: Flow type indicator. \(Re\): Reynolds number (<1000 laminar, >2000 turbulent), \(D\): characteristic length (diameter).
derivation:
The Reynolds number is a dimensionless quantity derived from the ratio of inertial forces to viscous forces.
Inertial Force \(\propto \rho v^2 L^2\)
Viscous Force \(\propto \eta v L\)
Ratio \(Re = \frac{\rho v^2 L^2}{\eta v L} = \frac{\rho v L}{\eta}\)

related_concepts.name: Laminar Flow
related_concepts.definition: Smooth, orderly fluid motion characterized by parallel layers (Low Re).

related_concepts.name: Turbulent Flow
related_concepts.definition: Chaotic fluid motion characterized by eddies and vortices (High Re).

subject: Physics
title: Poiseuille's Formula
description: Laminar flow rate in pipe. \(Q\): volume flow rate, \(\Delta P\): pressure drop, \(L\): length of pipe, \(r\): radius.
derivation:
Consider a cylindrical fluid element of radius \(r\) and length \(dx\).
The pressure force difference balances the viscous shear force.
\((\Delta P) \pi r^2 = -\eta (2\pi r L) \frac{dv}{dr}\)
Integrating velocity profile \(v(r)\) over the cross-section area gives the total flow rate \(Q\).
The result is proportional to \(r^4\), making flow very sensitive to radius.

related_concepts.name: Viscosity
related_concepts.definition: Fluid friction that resists flow.

related_concepts.name: Pressure Gradient
related_concepts.definition: The change in pressure per unit length along the pipe (\(\Delta P / L\)).

subject: Physics
title: Center of Pressure
description: Point of application of force. \(h_{cp}\): depth of center of pressure, \(h_{cg}\): depth of centroid, \(I_{cg}\): area moment of inertia.
derivation:
The center of pressure is where the resultant hydrostatic force acts.
It is calculated by taking moments of force about the surface.
\(h_{cp} = \frac{\int h dF}{\int dF}\)
Substituting \(dF = \rho g h dA\) and using the parallel axis theorem for moment of inertia:
\(h_{cp} = \frac{\rho g \int h^2 dA}{\rho g A h_{cg}} = \frac{I_{surface}}{A h_{cg}}\)
\(h_{cp} = h_{cg} + \frac{I_{cg}}{A h_{cg}}\)

related_concepts.name: Centroid
related_concepts.definition: The geometric center of the plane surface area.

related_concepts.name: Moment of Inertia
related_concepts.definition: A geometric property of an area that reflects how its points are distributed.

subject: Physics
title: Angular Velocity
description: Rate of change of angular displacement. \(\omega\): angular velocity [rad/s], \(\theta\): angle [rad], \(t\): time [s].
derivation:
Defined as the limit of average angular speed as time approaches zero.
\(\omega_{avg} = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}\)
Instantaneous angular velocity:
\(\omega = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t} = \frac{d\theta}{dt}\)

related_concepts.name: Radian
related_concepts.definition: The standard unit of angular measure.

subject: Physics
title: Angular Acceleration
description: Rate of change of angular velocity. \(\alpha\): angular acceleration [rad/s^2].
derivation:
Defined as the rate at which angular velocity changes over time.
\(\alpha = \frac{d}{dt}(\frac{d\theta}{dt}) = \frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}\)

related_concepts.name: Torque
related_concepts.definition: The rotational equivalent of force that causes angular acceleration (\(\tau = I\alpha\)).

subject: Physics
title: Relation: Linear & Angular
description: Linear velocity from angular velocity. \(v\): linear velocity, \(r\): position vector from rotation axis.
derivation:
For a particle moving in a circle of radius \(r\), the arc length is \(s = r\theta\).
Differentiating with respect to time:
\(\frac{ds}{dt} = r \frac{d\theta}{dt}\)
Since \(v = ds/dt\) and \(\omega = d\theta/dt\):
\(v = r\omega\)
In vector form:
\(\vec{v} = \vec{\omega} \times \vec{r}\)

related_concepts.name: Cross Product
related_concepts.definition: A vector operation where the result is perpendicular to both input vectors.

subject: Physics
title: Tangential Acceleration
description: Component of acceleration tangent to the path. \(r\): radius, \(\alpha\): angular acceleration.
derivation:
Tangential acceleration is the rate of change of the magnitude of velocity.
Since \(v = r\omega\) (assuming fixed \(r\)):
\(a_t = \frac{dv}{dt} = \frac{d(r\omega)}{dt} = r \frac{d\omega}{dt}\)
Substituting \(\alpha = d\omega/dt\):
\(a_t = r\alpha\)

related_concepts.name: Non-Uniform Circular Motion
related_concepts.definition: Motion in a circle where the speed is changing.

subject: Physics
title: Centripetal Acceleration
description: Component of acceleration directed towards the center. Responsible for changing direction.
derivation:
This acceleration arises from the change in direction of the velocity vector.
In vector calculus, \(\vec{a} = \frac{d\vec{v}}{dt}\).
For uniform circular motion, the direction changes constantly toward the center.
Magnitude derivation:
\(a_c = \frac{v^2}{r}\)
Substitute \(v = r\omega\):
\(a_c = \frac{(r\omega)^2}{r} = \omega^2 r\)

related_concepts.name: Centripetal Force
related_concepts.definition: The net force causing the centripetal acceleration (\(F_c = ma_c\)).

subject: Physics
title: Moment of Inertia
description: Rotational inertia. \(m_i\): mass of particle, \(r_i\): perpendicular distance from axis.
derivation:
Moment of Inertia is the rotational analog of mass.
Kinetic Energy of a rotating system is sum of kinetic energies of particles:
\(K = \sum \frac{1}{2}m_i v_i^2\)
Since \(v_i = r_i \omega\):
\(K = \sum \frac{1}{2}m_i (r_i \omega)^2 = \frac{1}{2} (\sum m_i r_i^2) \omega^2\)
Comparing to \(K = \frac{1}{2}I\omega^2\), we define:
\(I = \sum m_i r_i^2\)

related_concepts.name: Rotational Inertia
related_concepts.definition: Resistance of an object to changes in its rotational motion.

subject: Physics
title: MI: Uniform Rod (Center)
description: Axis perpendicular to rod passing through center of mass. \(M\): mass, \(L\): length.
derivation:
Consider a rod of length \(L\) and mass \(M\) along the x-axis.
Linear mass density \(\lambda = M/L\).
Consider a small element \(dx\) at distance \(x\) from the center.
Mass of element \(dm = \lambda dx\).
Calculate Moment of Inertia by integration from \(-L/2\) to \(L/2\):
\(I = \int r^2 dm = \int_{-L/2}^{L/2} x^2 (\frac{M}{L}) dx\)
\(I = \frac{M}{L} [\frac{x^3}{3}]_{-L/2}^{L/2}\)
\(I = \frac{M}{3L} (\frac{L^3}{8} - (-\frac{L^3}{8})) = \frac{M}{3L} (\frac{L^3}{4})\)
\(I = \frac{ML^2}{12}\)

related_concepts.name: Center of Mass
related_concepts.definition: The point where the weighted relative position of the distributed mass sums to zero.

subject: Physics
title: MI: Uniform Rod (End)
description: Axis perpendicular to rod passing through one end.
derivation:
Using the Parallel Axis Theorem:
\(I_{end} = I_{cm} + Md^2\)
Here, the distance \(d\) from center to end is \(L/2\).
\(I_{end} = \frac{ML^2}{12} + M(\frac{L}{2})^2\)
\(I_{end} = \frac{ML^2}{12} + \frac{ML^2}{4}\)
\(I_{end} = \frac{ML^2 + 3ML^2}{12} = \frac{4ML^2}{12}\)
\(I_{end} = \frac{ML^2}{3}\)

related_concepts.name: Parallel Axis Theorem
related_concepts.definition: Relates the MI about a centroidal axis to the MI about any parallel axis.

subject: Physics
title: MI: Ring (Center)
description: Axis passing through center and perpendicular to plane. \(M\): mass, \(R\): radius.
derivation:
Consider a ring of radius \(R\) and mass \(M\).
All the mass elements \(dm\) are at the same distance \(R\) from the axis.
\(I = \int r^2 dm\)
Since \(r = R\) is constant:
\(I = R^2 \int dm\)
\(I = MR^2\)

related_concepts.name: Thin Hoop
related_concepts.definition: Another name for a ring where thickness is negligible compared to radius.

subject: Physics
title: MI: Disc (Center)
description: Axis passing through center and perpendicular to plane.
derivation:
Divide the disc into thin concentric rings of radius \(r\) and width \(dr\).
Area density \(\sigma = \frac{M}{\pi R^2}\).
Area of element \(dA = 2\pi r dr\).
Mass of element \(dm = \sigma dA = \frac{M}{\pi R^2} (2\pi r dr) = \frac{2M}{R^2} r dr\).
Integrate moment of inertia of these rings (\(dI = dm \cdot r^2\)) from 0 to R:
\(I = \int_0^R (\frac{2M}{R^2} r) r^2 dr = \frac{2M}{R^2} \int_0^R r^3 dr\)
\(I = \frac{2M}{R^2} [\frac{r^4}{4}]_0^R = \frac{2M}{R^2} \frac{R^4}{4}\)
\(I = \frac{1}{2}MR^2\)

related_concepts.name: Surface Mass Density
related_concepts.definition: Mass per unit area (\(\sigma\)), used for 2D objects.

subject: Physics
title: MI: Solid Sphere
description: Axis passing through the center of a solid sphere.
derivation:
Slice the sphere into thin discs of thickness \(dx\) perpendicular to the x-axis.
For a disc at distance \(x\), radius \(y = \sqrt{R^2 - x^2}\).
Mass \(dm = \rho \pi y^2 dx\).
MI of disc \(dI = \frac{1}{2} dm y^2\).
Integrating from \(-R\) to \(R\):
\(I = \int_{-R}^{R} \frac{1}{2} (\rho \pi (R^2-x^2)) (R^2-x^2) dx\)
Solving the integral yields:
\(I = \frac{2}{5}MR^2\)

related_concepts.name: Volume Mass Density
related_concepts.definition: Mass per unit volume (\(\rho\)), used for 3D objects.

subject: Physics
title: MI: Hollow Sphere
description: Axis passing through the center of a thin spherical shell.
derivation:
Consider the hollow sphere as a sum of thin rings perpendicular to the axis.
Or, differentiate the formula for a solid sphere with respect to R.
Solid Sphere mass \(M = \frac{4}{3}\pi R^3 \rho\), so \(I = \frac{2}{5}(\frac{4}{3}\pi R^3 \rho) R^2 = \frac{8}{15}\pi \rho R^5\).
For a shell of thickness \(dR\), mass \(dM = 4\pi R^2 \rho dR\).
MI of shell \(dI = \frac{d}{dR}(\frac{8}{15}\pi \rho R^5) dR = \frac{8}{3}\pi \rho R^4 dR\).
Substitute \(\rho = \frac{M}{4\pi R^2 dR}\) (Shell mass density):
\(I = \frac{2}{3}MR^2\)

related_concepts.name: Spherical Shell
related_concepts.definition: A hollow sphere with negligible thickness.

subject: Physics
title: Parallel Axis Theorem
description: MI about any axis parallel to centroidal axis. \(d\): distance between axes.
derivation:
Let the center of mass (CM) be at the origin.
MI about axis through CM (z-axis): \(I_{cm} = \sum m_i (x_i^2 + y_i^2)\).
New axis is at distance \(d\) along x-axis (at \(x=d\)).
Distance of particle \(i\) from new axis is \(r'\).
\(r'^2 = (x_i - d)^2 + y_i^2 = x_i^2 - 2x_id + d^2 + y_i^2\).
\(I = \sum m_i r'^2 = \sum m_i(x_i^2 + y_i^2) + \sum m_i d^2 - 2d \sum m_i x_i\).
First term is \(I_{cm}\). Second is \(Md^2\). Third is 0 (definition of CM).
\(I = I_{cm} + Md^2\)

related_concepts.name: Centroidal Axis
related_concepts.definition: An axis passing through the body's center of mass.

subject: Physics
title: Perpendicular Axis Theorem
description: Valid ONLY for planar (2D) bodies. \(z\): axis perpendicular to plane, \(x, y\): axes in plane.
derivation:
Consider a planar body in the xy-plane.
Distance of a particle \(m_i\) from z-axis is \(r_i^2 = x_i^2 + y_i^2\).
\(I_z = \sum m_i r_i^2 = \sum m_i (x_i^2 + y_i^2)\)
Expand the sum:
\(I_z = \sum m_i x_i^2 + \sum m_i y_i^2\)
Note that \(\sum m_i x_i^2\) is actually \(I_y\) (distance from y-axis is x) and \(\sum m_i y_i^2\) is \(I_x\).
\(I_z = I_y + I_x\)

related_concepts.name: Planar Lamina
related_concepts.definition: A 2D flat body with uniform thickness and density.

subject: Physics
title: Torque
description: Moment of force. \(r\): position vector of point of application, \(F\): force vector.
derivation:
Torque represents the turning effect of a force.
Magnitude \(\tau = r F \sin \theta\), where \(\theta\) is angle between \(\vec{r}\) and \(\vec{F}\).
\(F \sin \theta\) is the component of force perpendicular to the radius vector.
In vector notation, this perpendicular relationship is defined by the cross product:
\(\vec{\tau} = \vec{r} \times \vec{F}\)

related_concepts.name: Lever Arm
related_concepts.definition: The perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation to the line of action of the force (\(r_{\perp} = r \sin \theta\)).

subject: Physics
title: Newton's 2nd Law (Rotation)
description: Net external torque causes angular acceleration.
derivation:
For a single particle: \(\tau = r F_t\) (tangential force).
From Newton's linear law: \(F_t = m a_t = m (r \alpha)\).
Substitute back: \(\tau = r (m r \alpha) = (m r^2) \alpha\).
Since \(I = mr^2\), we get \(\tau = I \alpha\).
Summing over all particles in a rigid body:
\(\sum \tau_{ext} = (\sum m_i r_i^2) \alpha = I \alpha\)

related_concepts.name: Rotational Inertia
related_concepts.definition: Resistance to change in angular velocity (Moment of Inertia).

subject: Physics
title: Angular Momentum (Particle)
description: Moment of linear momentum. \(p\): linear momentum.
derivation:
Defined analogously to torque (moment of force).
Angular momentum is the moment of linear momentum \(\vec{p}\).
\(\vec{L} = \vec{r} \times \vec{p}\)
Since \(\vec{p} = m\vec{v}\):
\(\vec{L} = m(\vec{r} \times \vec{v})\)

related_concepts.name: Linear Momentum
related_concepts.definition: The product of an object's mass and velocity (\(\vec{p} = m\vec{v}\)).

subject: Physics
title: Angular Momentum (Rigid Body)
description: For rotation about a fixed axis of symmetry.
derivation:
Sum the angular momenta of all particles in the body.
\(L_z = \sum L_i = \sum r_i p_i = \sum r_i (m_i v_i)\).
Substitute \(v_i = r_i \omega\):
\(L_z = \sum r_i (m_i r_i \omega) = (\sum m_i r_i^2) \omega\).
By definition \(I = \sum m_i r_i^2\):
\(L = I \omega\)

related_concepts.name: Principal Axis
related_concepts.definition: An axis of symmetry where the angular momentum vector is parallel to the angular velocity vector.

subject: Physics
title: Conservation of Angular Momentum
description: Valid when net external torque \(\tau_{ext} = 0\).
derivation:
From the rotational equivalent of Newton's second law:
\(\vec{\tau}_{ext} = \frac{d\vec{L}}{dt}\)
If \(\vec{\tau}_{ext} = 0\), then \(\frac{d\vec{L}}{dt} = 0\).
This implies \(\vec{L}\) is constant (conserved).
\(L_{initial} = L_{final}\)
\(I_1 \omega_1 = I_2 \omega_2\)

related_concepts.name: Isolated System
related_concepts.definition: A physical system so far removed from other systems that it does not interact with them.

subject: Physics
title: Rotational Kinetic Energy
description: Energy due to rotation. Analogous to \(\frac{1}{2}mv^2\).
derivation:
Total kinetic energy is the sum of KE of individual particles.
\(K = \sum \frac{1}{2} m_i v_i^2\)
Substitute \(v_i = r_i \omega\):
\(K = \sum \frac{1}{2} m_i (r_i \omega)^2\)
\(K = \frac{1}{2} (\sum m_i r_i^2) \omega^2\)
Since \(I = \sum m_i r_i^2\):
\(K_{rot} = \frac{1}{2} I \omega^2\)

related_concepts.name: Work-Energy Theorem
related_concepts.definition: Work done by torque equals the change in rotational kinetic energy.

subject: Physics
title: Total KE (Rolling)
description: Sum of translational KE of CM and rotational KE about CM.
derivation:
A rolling body has both translation and rotation.
Velocity of any particle: \(\vec{v}_i = \vec{v}_{cm} + \vec{v}'_i\) (relative to CM).
\(K = \sum \frac{1}{2} m_i (\vec{v}_{cm} + \vec{v}'_i)^2\)
Expanding yields two main terms (cross terms cancel due to CM definition):
1. Translational KE: \(\frac{1}{2} M v_{cm}^2\)
2. Rotational KE about CM: \(\frac{1}{2} I_{cm} \omega^2\)
Total \(K = K_{trans} + K_{rot}\)

related_concepts.name: Rolling without Slipping
related_concepts.definition: Condition where point of contact is instantaneously at rest (\(v_{cm} = R\omega\)).

subject: Physics
title: Pure Rolling Condition
description: Condition for no slipping at the point of contact on a stationary surface.
derivation:
For pure rolling, the point of contact must be instantaneously at rest relative to the surface.
Velocity of contact point \(v_P = v_{cm} - v_{rot}\)
Rotational velocity at rim is \(v_{rot} = R\omega\)
For no slipping, \(v_P = 0\)
\(v_{cm} - R\omega = 0\)
\(v_{cm} = R\omega\)

related_concepts.name: Instantaneous Axis of Rotation
related_concepts.definition: The axis about which the body is instantaneously rotating (at the contact point for rolling).

related_concepts.name: Friction
related_concepts.definition: Static friction is required to initiate or maintain pure rolling against external forces.

subject: Physics
title: Coulomb's Law
description: Force between point charges. \(\epsilon_0\): permittivity of free space, \(r\): separation distance.
derivation:
Coulomb's Law is an experimental law derived by Charles Coulomb.
It states force is proportional to product of charges and inversely proportional to square of distance.
\(F \propto q_1 q_2\) and \(F \propto 1/r^2\)
Combining them with constant \(k = 1/(4\pi\epsilon_0)\):
\(F = k \frac{q_1 q_2}{r^2}\)

related_concepts.name: Superposition Principle
related_concepts.definition: The net force on a charge is the vector sum of forces from all other charges.

related_concepts.name: Point Charge
related_concepts.definition: An idealized charge localized at a single point with no spatial extent.

subject: Physics
title: Electric Field (Point Charge)
description: Field intensity at distance \(r\). \(\hat{r}\): unit vector directed away from charge \(q\).
derivation:
Electric Field is defined as the force per unit positive test charge.
\(\vec{E} = \frac{\vec{F}}{q_0}\)
Using Coulomb's law for force between \(q\) and test charge \(q_0\):
\(\vec{F} = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q q_0}{r^2} \hat{r}\)
Dividing by \(q_0\):
\(\vec{E} = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{q}{r^2} \hat{r}\)

related_concepts.name: Test Charge
related_concepts.definition: A vanishingly small positive charge used to probe an electric field.

subject: Physics
title: Field due to Dipole (Axial)
description: Field on the axis of a short dipole. \(\vec{p}\): dipole moment, \(r\): distance from center.
derivation:
Calculate field at distance \(r\) from center on the axis.
\(E = E_+ - E_- = \frac{kq}{(r-a)^2} - \frac{kq}{(r+a)^2}\)
Simplify using algebraic expansion for \(r \gg a\):
\(E \approx k q \frac{4ar}{r^4} = \frac{2k(q \cdot 2a)}{r^3}\)
Since \(p = q(2a)\):
\(E = \frac{2kp}{r^3}\)

related_concepts.name: Electric Dipole
related_concepts.definition: A pair of equal and opposite point charges separated by a distance.

subject: Physics
title: Field due to Dipole (Equatorial)
description: Field on the perpendicular bisector. Direction is opposite to dipole moment \(\vec{p}\).
derivation:
At a point on the bisector, fields from \(+q\) and \(-q\) have equal magnitudes.
Vertical components cancel; horizontal components add up.
\(E_{net} = 2 E \cos \theta\)
\(\cos \theta = \frac{a}{\sqrt{r^2+a^2}}\)
For \(r \gg a\), this simplifies to:
\(E_{eq} = \frac{kp}{r^3}\) (Direction opposite to \(\vec{p}\))

related_concepts.name: Dipole Moment
related_concepts.definition: A vector quantity \(\vec{p} = q(2\vec{a})\) pointing from negative to positive charge.

subject: Physics
title: Torque on Dipole
description: Torque experienced by dipole in uniform electric field \(\vec{E}\).
derivation:
Forces on charges are \(\vec{F}_+ = q\vec{E}\) and \(\vec{F}_- = -q\vec{E}\).
Net force is zero, but they form a couple.
Torque \(\tau = \text{Force} \times \text{Perpendicular Distance}\)
\(\tau = (qE) \times (2a \sin \theta)\)
\(\tau = (q \cdot 2a) E \sin \theta = p E \sin \theta\)
In vector form:
\(\vec{\tau} = \vec{p} \times \vec{E}\)

related_concepts.name: Couple
related_concepts.definition: Two parallel forces of equal magnitude but opposite direction that produce rotation.

subject: Physics
title: Potential Energy of Dipole
description: Energy of dipole orientation. Stable equilibrium at \(\theta = 0\).
derivation:
Work done by external torque to rotate dipole from \(\theta_0\) to \(\theta_1\):
\(W = \int_{\theta_0}^{\theta_1} \tau_{ext} d\theta = \int pE \sin \theta d\theta\)
\(W = pE [-\cos \theta]_{\theta_0}^{\theta_1}\)
Defining \(U=0\) at \(\theta = 90^\circ\):
\(U(\theta) = -pE \cos \theta\)

related_concepts.name: Stable Equilibrium
related_concepts.definition: State where dipole aligns with the field (Minimum Energy).

subject: Physics
title: Gauss's Law
description: Net flux through closed surface equals enclosed charge divided by permittivity.
derivation:
Consider a point charge \(q\) inside a spherical surface of radius \(r\).
Flux \(\Phi = \oint E dA = E \oint dA\) (since E is constant on surface).
\(\Phi = (\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{q}{r^2}) (4\pi r^2)\)
\(\Phi = \frac{q}{\epsilon_0}\)
This result holds for any shape of closed surface enclosing the charge.

related_concepts.name: Electric Flux
related_concepts.definition: Measure of the number of electric field lines passing through a surface.

related_concepts.name: Gaussian Surface
related_concepts.definition: A hypothetical closed surface used to calculate electric field.

subject: Physics
title: Field: Line Charge
description: Infinite line charge. \(\lambda\): linear charge density [C/m], \(r\): perpendicular distance.
derivation:
Use a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius \(r\) and length \(L\).
Flux only passes through the curved surface (ends are parallel to E).
\(\Phi = E \times (2\pi r L)\)
Charge enclosed \(q_{in} = \lambda L\)
By Gauss's Law: \(E(2\pi r L) = \frac{\lambda L}{\epsilon_0}\)
\(E = \frac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0 r}\)

related_concepts.name: Linear Charge Density
related_concepts.definition: Charge per unit length (\(\lambda = dq/dL\)).

subject: Physics
title: Field: Infinite Sheet
description: Uniform field near a non-conducting sheet. \(\sigma\): surface charge density.
derivation:
Use a cylindrical 'pillbox' Gaussian surface cutting through the sheet.
Flux passes through two flat faces of area \(A\).
\(\Phi = EA + EA = 2EA\)
Charge enclosed \(q_{in} = \sigma A\)
By Gauss's Law: \(2EA = \frac{\sigma A}{\epsilon_0}\)
\(E = \frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}\)

related_concepts.name: Surface Charge Density
related_concepts.definition: Charge per unit area (\(\sigma = dq/dA\)).

subject: Physics
title: Field: Conductor Surface
description: Field just outside a charged conductor is normal to the surface.
derivation:
Inside a conductor, \(E=0\). Place a pillbox on the surface.
Flux is only through the outer cap of area \(A\).
\(\Phi = EA\)
Charge enclosed \(q_{in} = \sigma A\)
By Gauss's Law: \(EA = \frac{\sigma A}{\epsilon_0}\)
\(E = \frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_0}\)

related_concepts.name: Electrostatic Shielding
related_concepts.definition: The phenomenon where the electric field inside a cavity in a conductor is zero.

subject: Physics
title: Electric Potential
description: Scalar potential at distance \(r\) from point charge. Reference is zero at infinity.
derivation:
Potential is work done per unit charge from infinity to \(r\).
\(V = -\int_{\infty}^r \vec{E} \cdot d\vec{r}\)
\(V = -\int_{\infty}^r \frac{kq}{r'^2} dr'\)
\(V = -kq [-\frac{1}{r'}]_{\infty}^r\)
\(V = \frac{kq}{r}\)

related_concepts.name: Scalar Field
related_concepts.definition: A field characterized by a single magnitude at every point (unlike a vector field).

subject: Physics
title: Relation: E and V
description: Field is the negative gradient of potential. E flows from high to low V.
derivation:
Work done moving charge \(q\) by distance \(dx\) is \(dW = -qE dx\).
Change in potential energy is \(dU = q dV\).
So \(q dV = -qE dx\), which means \(E = -dV/dx\).
In 3D, this becomes the gradient vector:
\(\vec{E} = -(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\hat{i} + \frac{\partial V}{\partial y}\hat{j} + \frac{\partial V}{\partial z}\hat{k})\)

related_concepts.name: Equipotential Surface
related_concepts.definition: A surface where the potential is constant. Electric field lines are always perpendicular to it.

subject: Physics
title: Potential Energy of System
description: Work done to assemble two charges from infinity to separation \(r\).
derivation:
Bring charge \(q_1\) to location (Work = 0).
Bring charge \(q_2\) from infinity to distance \(r\) from \(q_1\).
Work done \(W = q_2 V_1\)
Substitute \(V_1 = \frac{kq_1}{r}\):
\(U = \frac{k q_1 q_2}{r}\)

related_concepts.name: Conservative Force
related_concepts.definition: A force where work done depends only on initial and final positions (Electrostatic force).

subject: Physics
title: Capacitance (Parallel Plate)
description: Capacity to store charge. \(\kappa\): dielectric constant, \(A\): area, \(d\): separation.
derivation:
Definition of capacitance: \(C = Q/V\).
Electric field between plates: \(E = \sigma / \epsilon_0 = Q / (A \epsilon_0)\).
Potential difference: \(V = Ed = \frac{Qd}{A \epsilon_0}\).
Substitute \(V\) into \(C = Q/V\):
\(C = \frac{Q}{Qd / A \epsilon_0} = \frac{\epsilon_0 A}{d}\)
With dielectric, multiply by \(\kappa\).

related_concepts.name: Dielectric
related_concepts.definition: An insulating material that increases capacitance by reducing the effective electric field.

subject: Physics
title: Energy in Capacitor
description: Potential energy stored in the electric field between plates.
derivation:
Work done to transfer small charge \(dq\) when potential is \(v\).
\(dW = v dq = \frac{q}{C} dq\)
Integrate from \(0\) to total charge \(Q\):
\(W = \int_0^Q \frac{q}{C} dq = \frac{1}{C} [\frac{q^2}{2}]_0^Q\)
\(U = \frac{Q^2}{2C}\)
Using \(Q=CV\), \(U = \frac{1}{2}CV^2\)

related_concepts.name: Energy Density
related_concepts.definition: Energy stored per unit volume in the electric field (\(u = \frac{1}{2}\epsilon_0 E^2\)).

subject: Physics
title: General Wave Equation
description: Progressive wave moving in +x direction. \(A\): amplitude, \(k\): wave number, \(\omega\): angular frequency.
derivation:
A wave maintains its shape while moving.
A function \(f(x, t)\) represents a wave if it is a function of \(x-vt\).
Sinusoidal form: \(y = A \sin(\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}(x - vt))\)
Substitute \(k = 2\pi/\lambda\) and \(\omega = 2\pi v/\lambda\):
\(y = A \sin(kx - \omega t)\)

related_concepts.name: Phase
related_concepts.definition: The argument of the sine function \((kx - \omega t + \phi)\), determining the state of oscillation.

subject: Physics
title: Wave Speed
description: Speed of wave propagation. \(f\): frequency [Hz], \(\lambda\): wavelength [m].
derivation:
Speed is distance over time.
A wave travels one wavelength \(\lambda\) in one time period \(T\).
\(v = \frac{\lambda}{T} = \lambda f\)
Using \(\omega = 2\pi f\) and \(k = 2\pi/\lambda\):
\(v = \frac{\omega/2\pi}{k/2\pi} = \frac{\omega}{k}\)

related_concepts.name: Phase Velocity
related_concepts.definition: The rate at which the phase of the wave propagates in space.

subject: Physics
title: Speed on Stretched String
description: Mechanical wave speed. \(T\): tension [N], \(\mu\): linear mass density [kg/m].
derivation:
Consider a small pulse element on a string under tension \(T\).
The restoring force providing centripetal acceleration is \(2T \sin(d\theta/2) \approx T d\theta\).
Mass of element \(dm = \mu (R d\theta)\).
Force equation: \(F = ma \Rightarrow T d\theta = (\mu R d\theta) \frac{v^2}{R}\)
\(T = \mu v^2\)
\(v = \sqrt{T/\mu}\)

related_concepts.name: Transverse Wave
related_concepts.definition: A wave where particle displacement is perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.

subject: Physics
title: Speed of Sound (Laplace)
description: Adiabatic process correction. \(\gamma\): adiabatic index, \(P\): pressure, \(\rho\): density.
derivation:
Newton assumed isothermal propagation: \(v = \sqrt{P/\rho}\) (Incorrect).
Laplace corrected this to adiabatic propagation because sound moves too fast for heat exchange.
Bulk Modulus for adiabatic process is \(B = \gamma P\).
General speed formula \(v = \sqrt{B/\rho}\) becomes:
\(v = \sqrt{\frac{\gamma P}{\rho}}\)

related_concepts.name: Adiabatic Process
related_concepts.definition: A thermodynamic process where no heat is exchanged with the surroundings.

subject: Physics
title: Standing Wave Equation
description: Superposition of two waves moving in opposite directions.
derivation:
Superpose two identical waves moving opposite directions:
\(y_1 = A \sin(kx - \omega t)\)
\(y_2 = A \sin(kx + \omega t)\)
Using trig identity \(\sin A + \sin B = 2 \sin(\frac{A+B}{2}) \cos(\frac{A-B}{2})\):
\(y = y_1 + y_2 = 2A \sin(kx) \cos(-\omega t)\)
\(y = 2A \sin(kx) \cos(\omega t)\)

related_concepts.name: Node
related_concepts.definition: Point of zero amplitude (\(\sin(kx) = 0\)).

related_concepts.name: Antinode
related_concepts.definition: Point of maximum amplitude (\(\sin(kx) = \pm 1\)).

subject: Physics
title: Beat Frequency
description: Periodic variation in amplitude due to superposition of waves with slightly different frequencies.
derivation:
Add two waves with frequencies \(\omega_1\) and \(\omega_2\).
\(y = A \sin(\omega_1 t) + A \sin(\omega_2 t)\)
\(y = 2A \cos(\frac{\omega_1-\omega_2}{2}t) \sin(\frac{\omega_1+\omega_2}{2}t)\)
The amplitude term is \(2A \cos(\frac{\Delta \omega}{2}t)\).
Intensity maxima occur twice per cycle of this cosine.
\(f_{beat} = 2 \times \frac{\Delta \omega / 2}{2\pi} = \frac{\Delta \omega}{2\pi} = f_1 - f_2\)

related_concepts.name: Interference
related_concepts.definition: The phenomenon where two waves superpose to form a resultant wave of greater, lower, or the same amplitude.

subject: Physics
title: Doppler Effect
description: Apparent frequency. \(v_o\): observer speed, \(v_s\): source speed. Top signs for approaching.
derivation:
Relies on relative velocity of wave fronts.
1. Moving Observer: The speed of waves relative to observer is \(v' = v \pm v_o\). \(f' = v'/\lambda = (v \pm v_o)/\lambda\).
2. Moving Source: The wavelength changes. \(\lambda' = (v \mp v_s)/f_0\).
Combining both:
\(f' = \frac{v'}{\lambda'} = \frac{v \pm v_o}{(v \mp v_s)/f_0} = f_0 \frac{v \pm v_o}{v \mp v_s}\)

related_concepts.name: Red Shift / Blue Shift
related_concepts.definition: Shift in frequency of light due to relative motion (Blue = approaching, Red = receding).

subject: Physics
title: Open Organ Pipe
description: Resonant frequencies for pipe open at both ends.
derivation:
In an open pipe, antinodes form at both open ends.
The simplest mode (fundamental) has length \(L = \frac{\lambda}{2}\).
General condition for standing waves: \(L = n \frac{\lambda_n}{2}\) for \(n=1,2,3...\)
Substitute \(\lambda_n = \frac{v}{f_n}\):
\(L = n \frac{v}{2f_n}\)
Solving for frequency:
\(f_n = \frac{nv}{2L}\)

related_concepts.name: Harmonics
related_concepts.definition: Integer multiples of the fundamental frequency (1st harmonic).

related_concepts.name: Antinode
related_concepts.definition: Point of maximum displacement amplitude (occurs at open ends).

subject: Physics
title: Closed Organ Pipe
description: Resonant frequencies for pipe closed at one end.
derivation:
Closed end is a Node (zero displacement); Open end is an Antinode.
Fundamental mode: \(L = \frac{\lambda}{4}\).
General condition (odd harmonics only): \(L = (2n-1)\frac{\lambda}{4}\).
Substitute \(\lambda = v/f\):
\(L = (2n-1)\frac{v}{4f}\)
\(f_n = \frac{(2n-1)v}{4L}\)

related_concepts.name: Node
related_concepts.definition: Point of zero displacement (occurs at the closed end/wall).

related_concepts.name: End Correction
related_concepts.definition: Small adjustment to length \(e \approx 0.6r\) because the antinode forms slightly outside the pipe.

subject: Physics
title: Mirror Formula
description: Relation for spherical mirrors. \(v\): image, \(u\): object, \(f\): focal length.
derivation:
Derived using geometry of similar triangles formed by the object, image, and Center of Curvature (C).
For paraxial rays (small angles):
\(\tan \alpha \approx \alpha\).
Using exterior angle theorem and geometric relations:
\(\frac{1}{v} + \frac{1}{u} = \frac{2}{R}\)
Since \(f = R/2\), we get:
\(\frac{1}{v} + \frac{1}{u} = \frac{1}{f}\)

related_concepts.name: Sign Convention
related_concepts.definition: Distances measured in the direction of incident light are positive; opposite are negative.

related_concepts.name: Paraxial Rays
related_concepts.definition: Rays close to the principal axis making small angles.

subject: Physics
title: Lens Formula
description: Thin lens equation.
derivation:
Consider a thin convex lens.
Triangles formed by the object and optical center are similar to those of the image and optical center.
\(\frac{h'}{h} = \frac{v}{u}\) (Magnification)
Using the focus, another set of similar triangles gives:
\(\frac{h'}{h} = \frac{v-f}{f}\)
Equating and simplifying yields:
\(\frac{1}{v} - \frac{1}{u} = \frac{1}{f}\)

related_concepts.name: Thin Lens Approximation
related_concepts.definition: Assumption that lens thickness is negligible compared to radii of curvature.

subject: Physics
title: Lens Maker's Formula
description: Focal length from geometry.
derivation:
Apply the refraction formula at a spherical surface twice.
Surface 1 (Air to Glass): \(\frac{\mu}{v_1} - \frac{1}{u} = \frac{\mu-1}{R_1}\)
Surface 2 (Glass to Air): Image from surface 1 acts as object.
\(\frac{1}{v} - \frac{\mu}{v_1} = \frac{1-\mu}{R_2}\)
Adding both equations cancels \(\frac{\mu}{v_1}\):
\(\frac{1}{v} - \frac{1}{u} = (\mu-1)(\frac{1}{R_1} - \frac{1}{R_2})\)
Since \(1/v - 1/u = 1/f\), the result follows.

related_concepts.name: Refractive Index
related_concepts.definition: Ratio of speed of light in vacuum to speed in the medium (\(n = c/v\)).

subject: Physics
title: Snell's Law
description: Refraction at interface.
derivation:
Derived from Fermat's Principle of Least Time.
Light takes the path that minimizes travel time.
\(t = \frac{d_1}{v_1} + \frac{d_2}{v_2} = \frac{d_1 n_1}{c} + \frac{d_2 n_2}{c}\)
Differentiating with respect to position on interface and setting to 0 yields:
\(n_1 \sin i = n_2 \sin r\)

related_concepts.name: Critical Angle
related_concepts.definition: Angle of incidence where angle of refraction is 90°, leading to Total Internal Reflection.

subject: Physics
title: Prism Formula
description: Refractive index of prism.
derivation:
For a prism, deviation \(\delta = (i + e) - A\).
At minimum deviation \(\delta_m\), the ray passes symmetrically:
\(i = e\) and \(r_1 = r_2 = r\).
From geometry, \(A = r_1 + r_2 = 2r \Rightarrow r = A/2\).
Also \(\delta_m = 2i - A \Rightarrow i = (A+\delta_m)/2\).
By Snell's Law \(\mu = \frac{\sin i}{\sin r}\), we get the formula.

related_concepts.name: Minimum Deviation
related_concepts.definition: The smallest angle of deviation, occurring when light travels parallel to the prism base.

subject: Physics
title: Biot-Savart Law
description: Magnetic field due to current element.
derivation:
An experimental inverse-square law for magnetism.
Field \(dB\) is proportional to current \(I\), element length \(dl\), sine of angle, and \(1/r^2\).
\(dB \propto \frac{I dl \sin \theta}{r^2}\)
Constant of proportionality is \(\frac{\mu_0}{4\pi}\).

related_concepts.name: Permeability of Free Space
related_concepts.definition: \(\mu_0 = 4\pi \times 10^{-7} T\cdot m/A\). Measure of vacuum's support for magnetic fields.

subject: Physics
title: Field: Infinite Wire
description: Field at distance \(r\) from long straight wire.
derivation:
Using Ampere's Circuital Law:
Consider a circular loop of radius \(r\) around the wire.
By symmetry, \(B\) is constant and tangential.
\(\oint \vec{B} \cdot d\vec{l} = B(2\pi r)\)
Current enclosed is \(I\).
\(B(2\pi r) = \mu_0 I\)
\(B = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi r}\)

related_concepts.name: Ampere's Law
related_concepts.definition: The line integral of B-field around a closed loop equals \(\mu_0\) times enclosed current.

subject: Physics
title: Field: Arc Center
description: Field at center of circular arc.
derivation:
Use Biot-Savart Law for element \(dl\).
Angle between \(dl\) and \(r\) is always 90° (\(\sin 90 = 1\)).
\(dB = \frac{\mu_0 I dl}{4\pi R^2}\)
Integrate \(dl\) over the arc length \(L = R\theta\):
\(B = \int \frac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi R^2} dl = \frac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi R^2} (R\theta)\)
\(B = \frac{\mu_0 I \theta}{4\pi R}\)

related_concepts.name: Right Hand Thumb Rule
related_concepts.definition: Determines direction of magnetic field lines around a current-carrying conductor.

subject: Physics
title: Field: Solenoid
description: Uniform field inside long solenoid.
derivation:
Use Ampere's Law on a rectangular loop partially inside the solenoid.
Only the side inside (length \(h\)) contributes to integral (\(B\cdot h\)).
Sides perpendicular give 0; side outside gives 0 (weak field).
\(\oint B \cdot dl = Bh\)
Enclosed current \(I_{in} = (nh)I\) where \(n\) is turns/length.
\(Bh = \mu_0 (nh I)\)
\(B = \mu_0 n I\)

related_concepts.name: Ideal Solenoid
related_concepts.definition: A solenoid with infinite length, creating a perfectly uniform internal field.

subject: Physics
title: Lorentz Force
description: Magnetic force on moving charge.
derivation:
This is an empirical definition of the Magnetic Field \(B\).
The force is observed to be proportional to charge, velocity, and field, and perpendicular to both \(v\) and \(B\).
Since force is perpendicular to motion, magnetic force does NO WORK.

related_concepts.name: Cyclotron Motion
related_concepts.definition: Circular motion of a charged particle in a uniform magnetic field.

subject: Physics
title: Cyclotron Radius
description: Motion of charge \(q\) entering \(B\) perpendicularly.
derivation:
For circular motion, magnetic force provides centripetal force.
\(F_B = F_c\)
\(qvB = \frac{mv^2}{r}\) (assuming \(v \perp B\))
Cancel \(v\) and solve for \(r\):
\(r = \frac{mv}{qB}\)

related_concepts.name: Time Period
related_concepts.definition: \(T = 2\pi m / qB\). Notably independent of velocity (basis of cyclotron).

subject: Physics
title: Force on Wire
description: Force on straight wire in uniform field.
derivation:
Consider free electrons in wire with drift velocity \(v_d\).
Force on one electron: \(\vec{f} = -e(\vec{v}_d \times \vec{B})\)
Total force = (Force per e) × (Number of e).
\(N = nAl\).
\(\vec{F} = nAl \cdot (-e \vec{v}_d \times \vec{B})\)
Since \(I = -neAv_d\), we substitute \(I\vec{l}\) for \(-neA\vec{v}_d l\):
\(\vec{F} = I(\vec{l} \times \vec{B})\)

related_concepts.name: Fleming's Left Hand Rule
related_concepts.definition: Mnemonic for direction of Force (Thumb), Field (Index), and Current (Middle).

subject: Physics
title: Force: Parallel Wires
description: Force per unit length between currents.
derivation:
Wire 1 creates field \(B_1\) at location of Wire 2.
\(B_1 = \frac{\mu_0 I_1}{2\pi d}\)
Force on length \(l\) of Wire 2: \(F_2 = I_2 l B_1\).
\(F_2 = I_2 l (\frac{\mu_0 I_1}{2\pi d})\)
Force per unit length:
\(\frac{F}{l} = \frac{\mu_0 I_1 I_2}{2\pi d}\)

related_concepts.name: Definition of Ampere
related_concepts.definition: The current which, in two parallel wires 1m apart, yields force \(2 \times 10^{-7} N/m\).

subject: Physics
title: Magnetic Dipole Moment
description: For a current loop. \(N\): turns, \(A\): area.
derivation:
Defined by analogy to electric dipoles.
A current loop creates a field similar to a bar magnet.
The strength is proportional to current \(I\) and Area \(A\).
Direction is given by Right Hand Curl Rule.

related_concepts.name: Bohr Magneton
related_concepts.definition: The natural unit for expressing the magnetic moment of an electron caused by its orbital or spin angular momentum.

subject: Physics
title: Torque on Dipole
description: Torque aligning dipole with field.
derivation:
Consider a rectangular loop \(a \times b\) in field \(B\).
Forces on sides \(b\) (parallel to axis) cancel.
Forces on sides \(a\) are \(F = IaB\), creating a couple.
Torque \(\tau = F \times (b \sin \theta) = (IaB) (b \sin \theta)\)
\(\tau = I(ab) B \sin \theta = IAB \sin \theta\)
Using \(M = IA\):
\(\vec{\tau} = \vec{M} \times \vec{B}\)

related_concepts.name: Galvanometer Principle
related_concepts.definition: Current-carrying coil in magnetic field experiences torque, deflecting a needle.

subject: Physics
title: Faraday's Law
description: Induced EMF equals negative rate of change of magnetic flux.
derivation:
Experimental law discovered by Michael Faraday.
The magnitude of induced EMF is proportional to rate of change of magnetic flux.
\(|\varepsilon| = \frac{d\Phi}{dt}\)
The negative sign (Lenz's Law) indicates the direction opposes the change.

related_concepts.name: Lenz's Law
related_concepts.definition: The direction of induced current is such that it opposes the change in magnetic flux that produced it.

subject: Physics
title: Magnetic Flux
description: Scalar product of Magnetic field and Area vector.
derivation:
Flux measures the 'flow' of field lines through a surface.
Defined as dot product \(BA \cos \theta\).
Max flux when surface is perpendicular to field (\(\theta=0\)).
Zero flux when parallel.

related_concepts.name: Weber (Wb)
related_concepts.definition: SI unit of magnetic flux (\(1 Wb = 1 T m^2\)).

subject: Physics
title: Motional EMF
description: EMF induced in a conductor moving in B-field.
derivation:
Conductor of length \(l\) moves with \(v\) in field \(B\).
Force on free electron \(F_m = qvB\) pushes it to one end.
Charge separation creates electric field \(E\) and force \(F_e = qE\).
Equilibrium: \(qE = qvB \Rightarrow E = vB\).
Potential difference (EMF) \(\varepsilon = El = vBl\).

related_concepts.name: Energy Conservation
related_concepts.definition: Mechanical power required to pull the conductor appears as electrical power (\(P = Fv = \varepsilon I\)).

subject: Physics
title: Self Inductance (Solenoid)
description: Inductance of a long solenoid.
derivation:
Total flux linkage \(N\Phi\).
Flux per turn \(\Phi = BA = (\mu_0 n I)A\).
Total turns \(N = nl\).
Total flux \(N\Phi = (nl)(\mu_0 n I A) = \mu_0 n^2 A l I\).
By definition \(N\Phi = LI\).
\(L = \mu_0 n^2 A l\)

related_concepts.name: Back EMF
related_concepts.definition: EMF induced in the inductor opposing the change in current (\(\varepsilon = -L di/dt\)).

subject: Physics
title: Energy in Inductor
description: Magnetic potential energy stored in an inductor.
derivation:
Power required to drive current against back EMF is \(P = |\varepsilon| I = L \frac{di}{dt} I\).
Work done in time \(dt\): \(dW = P dt = L I di\).
Integrate from 0 to \(I\):
\(W = \int_0^I L I di = L [\frac{I^2}{2}]_0^I\)
\(U = \frac{1}{2} L I^2\)

related_concepts.name: Magnetic Energy Density
related_concepts.definition: Energy per unit volume in magnetic field \(u_B = B^2 / 2\mu_0\).

subject: Physics
title: RMS Current
description: Root Mean Square value for sinusoidal AC.
derivation:
RMS is the DC equivalent for heating power.
Average power \(P = <I^2 R> = R <I_0^2 \sin^2 \omega t>\).
Average of \(\sin^2\) over a cycle is \(1/2\).
\(P = R \frac{I_0^2}{2}\).
Equating to DC power \(I_{rms}^2 R\):
\(I_{rms}^2 = I_0^2 / 2 \Rightarrow I_{rms} = I_0 / \sqrt{2}\)

related_concepts.name: Peak Value
related_concepts.definition: The maximum amplitude \(I_0\) of the alternating current.

subject: Physics
title: Inductive Reactance
description: Opposition to current flow by inductor.
derivation:
In purely inductive circuit, \(V = L di/dt\).
If \(i = I_0 \sin \omega t\), then \(di/dt = I_0 \omega \cos \omega t\).
\(V = L I_0 \omega \cos \omega t = V_0 \sin(\omega t + \pi/2)\).
Comparing amplitudes: \(V_0 = I_0 (\omega L)\).
This acts like resistance: \(X_L = \omega L\).

related_concepts.name: Phase Lead
related_concepts.definition: In an inductor, voltage leads current by 90° (\(\pi/2\)).

subject: Physics
title: Capacitive Reactance
description: Opposition to current flow by capacitor.
derivation:
In purely capacitive circuit, \(q = CV\).
\(i = dq/dt = C dV/dt\).
If \(V = V_0 \sin \omega t\), then \(i = C V_0 \omega \cos \omega t\).
\(i = \frac{V_0}{1/\omega C} \sin(\omega t + \pi/2)\).
Resistance-like term: \(X_C = \frac{1}{\omega C}\).

related_concepts.name: Phase Lag
related_concepts.definition: In a capacitor, voltage lags behind current by 90° (\(\pi/2\)).

subject: Physics
title: Impedance (LCR)
description: Total opposition in RLC circuit.
derivation:
Using Phasor Diagram:
Resistor voltage \(V_R\) is in phase with \(I\).
Inductor \(V_L\) leads by 90°; Capacitor \(V_C\) lags by 90°.
Net reactive voltage is \(V_L - V_C\).
Total voltage \(V = \sqrt{V_R^2 + (V_L - V_C)^2}\).
Dividing by \(I\):
\(Z = \sqrt{R^2 + (X_L - X_C)^2}\)

related_concepts.name: Phasor Diagram
related_concepts.definition: Graphical representation of AC voltages and currents as rotating vectors.

subject: Physics
title: Resonance Frequency
description: Frequency where impedance is minimum (Z=R).
derivation:
Resonance occurs when current is maximum.
This happens when Impedance \(Z\) is minimum.
\(Z = \sqrt{R^2 + (X_L - X_C)^2}\) is min when \(X_L = X_C\).
\(\omega L = \frac{1}{\omega C}\)
\(\omega^2 = \frac{1}{LC}\)
\(\omega_0 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}\)

related_concepts.name: Q-Factor
related_concepts.definition: Quality factor, determines sharpness of resonance (\(Q = \frac{1}{R}\sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}\)).

subject: Physics
title: Power Factor
description: Ratio of true power to apparent power.
derivation:
Average power in AC: \(P = V_{rms} I_{rms} \cos \phi\).
From impedance triangle:
Base is \(R\), Hypotenuse is \(Z\), Angle is \(\phi\).
\(\cos \phi = \text{Adjacent}/\text{Hypotenuse} = R/Z\).
Max power at resonance (\(\cos \phi = 1\)).

related_concepts.name: Wattless Current
related_concepts.definition: Current component in pure inductor/capacitor that consumes zero average power.

subject: Physics
title: Transformer Ratio
description: Ideal transformer relation.
derivation:
Based on Faraday's Law.
Flux \(\Phi\) is same through primary and secondary (ideal core).
\(V_p = -N_p \frac{d\Phi}{dt}\)
\(V_s = -N_s \frac{d\Phi}{dt}\)
Dividing equations: \(\frac{V_s}{V_p} = \frac{N_s}{N_p}\).
For power conservation (\(P_{in} = P_{out}\)): \(V_p I_p = V_s I_s\).

related_concepts.name: Step-Up/Step-Down
related_concepts.definition: Step-up increases voltage (\(N_s > N_p\)); Step-down decreases voltage.

subject: Physics
title: Drift Velocity
description: Avg velocity of electrons.
derivation:
Force on electron \(F = eE\).
Acceleration \(a = eE/m\).
Electrons accelerate for average time \(\tau\) (relaxation time) before collision.
\(v_d = a \tau = \frac{eE}{m}\tau\).
Relation to current: \(I = nAe v_d\).

related_concepts.name: Relaxation Time
related_concepts.definition: Average time interval between two successive collisions of electrons.

subject: Physics
title: Current Density
description: Vector form of Ohm's Law.
derivation:
Current density \(J = I/A\).
Substitute \(I = nAe v_d\): \(J = ne v_d\).
Substitute \(v_d = \frac{eE\tau}{m}\):
\(J = \frac{ne^2\tau}{m} E\)
The term \(\frac{ne^2\tau}{m}\) is conductivity \(\sigma\).
\(\vec{J} = \sigma \vec{E}\)

related_concepts.name: Conductivity
related_concepts.definition: Measure of a material's ability to conduct current (Inverse of resistivity).

subject: Physics
title: Resistivity (Temp)
description: Linear approx for metals.
derivation:
For metals, resistivity increases with temperature due to increased collisions (lower \(\tau\)).
Approximated as a linear expansion series around reference \(T_0\).
\(\Delta \rho \propto \Delta T\) and original \(\rho_0\).
\(\Delta \rho = \rho_0 \alpha \Delta T\)
\(\rho_T = \rho_0 + \rho_0 \alpha (T-T_0)\)

related_concepts.name: Temp Coefficient
related_concepts.definition: \(\alpha\): Fractional change in resistivity per degree change in temperature.

subject: Physics
title: KCL (Current Law)
description: Conservation of charge at a junction.
derivation:
Based on Conservation of Charge.
Charge cannot accumulate at a junction point (node) in steady state.
Total charge entering per second must equal total charge leaving per second.

related_concepts.name: Nodal Analysis
related_concepts.definition: Circuit analysis method using KCL to find node voltages.

subject: Physics
title: KVL (Voltage Law)
description: Conservation of energy in a closed loop.
derivation:
Based on Conservation of Energy.
Electrostatic force is conservative.
Work done moving a unit charge around a closed loop is zero.
Sum of potential drops (resistors) and gains (batteries) is zero.

related_concepts.name: Mesh Analysis
related_concepts.definition: Circuit analysis method using KVL to find loop currents.

subject: Physics
title: Wheatstone Bridge
description: Null point condition. No current flows through the galvanometer.
derivation:
Bridge is balanced when potential at nodes B and D is equal ($V_B = V_D$).
Current through galvanometer $I_g = 0$.
Apply KVL to left loop: $I_1 R_1 - I_3 R_3 = 0 \implies I_1 R_1 = I_3 R_3$.
Apply KVL to right loop: $I_2 R_2 - I_4 R_4 = 0 \implies I_2 R_2 = I_4 R_4$.
Since $I_g=0$, $I_1 = I_2$ and $I_3 = I_4$.
Dividing equations: $\frac{R_1}{R_2} = \frac{R_3}{R_4}$

related_concepts.name: Null Method
related_concepts.definition: Measurement technique where zero reading indicates balance, eliminating error due to internal resistance of the meter.

subject: Physics
title: Meter Bridge
description: Unknown resistance $R$ using standard $S$ and balance length $l$.
derivation:
Based on Wheatstone Bridge principle.
Wire AC is 100cm long with uniform resistance per cm $\rho$.
Resistance of length $l$: $P = \rho l$.
Resistance of length $(100-l)$: $Q = \rho(100-l)$.
At balance: $\frac{R}{S} = \frac{P}{Q} = \frac{\rho l}{\rho(100-l)}$.
$R = S \frac{l}{100-l}$

related_concepts.name: End Error
related_concepts.definition: Error caused when the zero mark of the scale does not coincide exactly with the start of the bridge wire.

subject: Physics
title: Potentiometer (EMF)
description: Comparing EMFs of two cells using balancing lengths.
derivation:
Potential drop across potentiometer wire is proportional to length ($V \propto l$).
For cell 1, balance length is $l_1$: $\varepsilon_1 = k l_1$.
For cell 2, balance length is $l_2$: $\varepsilon_2 = k l_2$.
Dividing the two equations eliminates the potential gradient $k$.
$\frac{\varepsilon_1}{\varepsilon_2} = \frac{l_1}{l_2}$

related_concepts.name: Potential Gradient
related_concepts.definition: Potential drop per unit length along the potentiometer wire ($k = V/L$).

subject: Physics
title: Internal Resistance
description: Internal resistance of cell via Potentiometer.
derivation:
Open circuit (no current drawn): $\varepsilon = k l_1$.
Closed circuit with external $R$: Terminal voltage $V = k l_2$.
We know $V = \frac{\varepsilon R}{R+r}$.
$\frac{\varepsilon}{V} = \frac{l_1}{l_2} = \frac{R+r}{R}$.
$\frac{l_1}{l_2} = 1 + \frac{r}{R}$.
$r = R(\frac{l_1}{l_2} - 1)$

related_concepts.name: Terminal Voltage
related_concepts.definition: Voltage output of a source when current is flowing ($V = \varepsilon - Ir$).

subject: Physics
title: Power in Circuit
description: Rate of heat dissipation or energy consumption.
derivation:
Work done moving charge $dQ$ across potential $V$ is $dW = V dQ$.
Power $P = \frac{dW}{dt} = V \frac{dQ}{dt} = VI$.
Using Ohm's Law ($V=IR$):
1. $P = (IR)I = I^2 R$ (Series/Current constant).
2. $P = V(V/R) = V^2/R$ (Parallel/Voltage constant).

related_concepts.name: Joule Heating
related_concepts.definition: Process where energy of electric current is converted into heat ($H = I^2 Rt$).

subject: Physics
title: Gravitational Field
description: Field strength at surface of planet mass $M$, radius $R$.
derivation:
Force on mass $m$ at surface: $F = \frac{G M m}{R^2}$.
Acceleration due to gravity $g = \frac{F}{m}$.
$g = \frac{GM}{R^2}$

related_concepts.name: Universal Gravitational Constant
related_concepts.definition: $G \approx 6.67 \times 10^{-11} N m^2/kg^2$.

subject: Physics
title: Variation of g (Height)
description: Valid for small heights $h \ll R$.
derivation:
At height $h$: $g_h = \frac{GM}{(R+h)^2} = \frac{GM}{R^2(1+h/R)^2}$.
$g_h = g (1 + \frac{h}{R})^{-2}$.
Using Binomial expansion for $x \ll 1$: $(1+x)^n \approx 1+nx$.
$g_h \approx g (1 - \frac{2h}{R})$

related_concepts.name: Binomial Approximation
related_concepts.definition: Mathematical tool $(1+x)^n \approx 1+nx$ used when $x$ is very small.

subject: Physics
title: Variation of g (Depth)
description: Acceleration due to gravity at depth $d$.
derivation:
At depth $d$, only the inner sphere of radius $(R-d)$ contributes.
Mass $M' = \frac{M}{4/3\pi R^3} \times \frac{4}{3}\pi (R-d)^3 = M \frac{(R-d)^3}{R^3}$.
$g_d = \frac{G M'}{(R-d)^2} = \frac{G M (R-d)}{R^3}$.
Substitute $g = GM/R^2$: $g_d = g \frac{R-d}{R} = g(1 - d/R)$.

related_concepts.name: Shell Theorem
related_concepts.definition: A spherical shell exerts no gravitational force on a particle inside it.

subject: Physics
title: Escape Velocity
description: Min speed to escape gravitational field.
derivation:
Conservation of Energy: Initial Total Energy = Final Total Energy (at $\infty$).
$K_i + U_i = 0$ (Just escapes).
$\frac{1}{2}m v_e^2 - \frac{GMm}{R} = 0$.
$v_e^2 = \frac{2GM}{R}$.
$v_e = \sqrt{2gR}$

related_concepts.name: Binding Energy
related_concepts.definition: Energy required to move a satellite from its orbit to infinity.

subject: Physics
title: Orbital Velocity
description: Speed of satellite in circular orbit.
derivation:
Gravitational force provides necessary centripetal force.
$F_g = F_c \implies \frac{GMm}{r^2} = \frac{m v_o^2}{r}$.
$v_o^2 = \frac{GM}{r}$.
$v_o = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}}$

related_concepts.name: Geostationary Orbit
related_concepts.definition: Orbit where $T=24$ hrs, keeping satellite fixed relative to Earth.

subject: Physics
title: Kepler's Third Law
description: Square of time period proportional to cube of radius.
derivation:
Time period $T = \frac{\text{Circumference}}{\text{Speed}} = \frac{2\pi r}{v_o}$.
Substitute $v_o = \sqrt{GM/r}$.
$T = 2\pi r \sqrt{\frac{r}{GM}} = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{r^3}{GM}}$.
Squaring both sides:
$T^2 = \frac{4\pi^2}{GM} r^3$

related_concepts.name: Areal Velocity
related_concepts.definition: Kepler's 2nd Law: Areal velocity ($dA/dt$) is constant ($L/2m$).

subject: Physics
title: SHM Displacement
description: Position in Simple Harmonic Motion.
derivation:
From differential equation $\frac{d^2x}{dt^2} + \omega^2 x = 0$.
General solution is sinusoidal.
$A$ is amplitude (max displacement).
$\omega$ is angular frequency (rate of phase change).
$\phi$ is initial phase (at $t=0$).

related_concepts.name: Phase Constant
related_concepts.definition: Determines the starting position and direction of motion at $t=0$.

subject: Physics
title: SHM Velocity
description: Velocity as function of position.
derivation:
$v = \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(A \cos(\omega t))$.
$v = -A\omega \sin(\omega t)$.
Using $\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1$:
$\sin(\omega t) = \sqrt{1 - \cos^2(\omega t)} = \sqrt{1 - (x/A)^2}$.
$v = -A\omega \sqrt{\frac{A^2-x^2}{A^2}} = \pm \omega \sqrt{A^2-x^2}$

related_concepts.name: Mean Position
related_concepts.definition: Position where net force is zero and velocity is maximum ($v_{max} = A\omega$).

subject: Physics
title: SHM Acceleration
description: Acceleration is proportional to displacement.
derivation:
$a = \frac{dv}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(-A\omega \sin(\omega t))$.
$a = -A\omega^2 \cos(\omega t)$.
Since $x = A \cos(\omega t)$:
$a = -\omega^2 x$

related_concepts.name: Restoring Force
related_concepts.definition: Force always directed towards equilibrium ($F = ma = -m\omega^2 x = -kx$).

subject: Physics
title: Time Period (Spring)
description: Mass $m$ on spring $k$.
derivation:
Restoring force $F = -kx$.
Newton's Law $F = ma$.
$ma = -kx \implies a = -\frac{k}{m} x$.
Compare with SHM eq $a = -\omega^2 x$:
$\omega^2 = k/m \implies \omega = \sqrt{k/m}$.
$T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega} = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}$

related_concepts.name: Inertia Factor
related_concepts.definition: Mass ($m$) represents inertia; Spring constant ($k$) represents stiffness.

subject: Physics
title: Simple Pendulum
description: Valid for small angles.
derivation:
Restoring torque $\tau = -mgL \sin \theta$.
For small $\theta$, $\sin \theta \approx \theta$.
$\tau = -mgL \theta = I \alpha$.
$mL^2 \alpha = -mgL \theta \implies \alpha = -\frac{g}{L} \theta$.
Compare with $\alpha = -\omega^2 \theta$:
$\omega = \sqrt{g/L} \implies T = 2\pi \sqrt{L/g}$

related_concepts.name: Seconds Pendulum
related_concepts.definition: A pendulum with a time period of exactly 2 seconds.

subject: Physics
title: Springs in Series
description: Force is same, extension adds up.
derivation:
Total extension $x = x_1 + x_2$.
Force $F$ is same in both springs.
$x_1 = F/k_1, x_2 = F/k_2$.
$x = F(\frac{1}{k_1} + \frac{1}{k_2})$.
Since $x = F/k_{eq}$:
$\frac{1}{k_{eq}} = \frac{1}{k_1} + \frac{1}{k_2}$

related_concepts.name: Effective Stiffness
related_concepts.definition: Series connection reduces overall stiffness (softer system).

subject: Physics
title: Springs in Parallel
description: Extension is same, force adds up.
derivation:
Both springs extend by same amount $x$.
Total force $F = F_1 + F_2$.
$F_1 = k_1 x, F_2 = k_2 x$.
$F = (k_1 + k_2)x$.
Since $F = k_{eq} x$:
$k_{eq} = k_1 + k_2$

related_concepts.name: Effective Stiffness
related_concepts.definition: Parallel connection increases overall stiffness (stiffer system).

subject: Physics
title: Total Energy in SHM
description: Constant sum of Kinetic and Potential energy.
derivation:
$K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}m\omega^2 A^2 \sin^2(\omega t)$.
$U = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = \frac{1}{2}m\omega^2 A^2 \cos^2(\omega t)$.
$E = K + U = \frac{1}{2}m\omega^2 A^2 (\sin^2 + \cos^2)$.
$E = \frac{1}{2}m\omega^2 A^2$

related_concepts.name: Conservation of Mechanical Energy
related_concepts.definition: In ideal SHM (no damping), energy oscillates between K and U but total remains constant.

subject: Physics
title: Compound Pendulum
description: Physical pendulum time period.
derivation:
Restoring torque about pivot $\tau = -mgd \sin \theta$.
$I \alpha = -mgd \theta$ (small angle).
$\alpha = -\frac{mgd}{I} \theta$.
$\omega^2 = \frac{mgd}{I}$.
$T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega} = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{I}{mgd}}$

related_concepts.name: Radius of Gyration
related_concepts.definition: Distance $k$ such that $I = mk^2$. Used to simplify the formula.

subject: Physics
title: Damped Amplitude
description: Decay of amplitude due to damping.
derivation:
Damping force $F_d = -bv$.
Equation: $ma + bv + kx = 0$.
Solution form is $x(t) = A_0 e^{-bt/2m} \cos(\omega' t + \phi)$.
The amplitude term decays exponentially.

related_concepts.name: Critical Damping
related_concepts.definition: Condition ($b = 2\sqrt{mk}$) where system returns to equilibrium fastest without oscillating.

subject: Physics
title: Photoelectric Equation
description: Einstein's photoelectric equation.
derivation:
Based on Conservation of Energy.
Photon Energy = Work Function + Kinetic Energy.
$E = \Phi + K_{max}$.
$h\nu = \Phi + K_{max}$.
$K_{max} = h\nu - \Phi$

related_concepts.name: Work Function
related_concepts.definition: Minimum energy required to eject an electron from a metal surface.

subject: Physics
title: Stopping Potential
description: Retarding potential to stop electrons.
derivation:
Work done by stopping potential $V_s$ on electron equals its max kinetic energy.
$W = \Delta K \implies -eV_s = 0 - K_{max}$.
$K_{max} = eV_s$.
Substituting into Einstein's equation:
$eV_s = h\nu - \Phi$

related_concepts.name: Threshold Frequency
related_concepts.definition: Minimum frequency $\nu_0$ required for photo-emission ($\Phi = h\nu_0$).

subject: Physics
title: De Broglie Wavelength
description: Wave nature of matter.
derivation:
For a photon, $E = h\nu = hc/\lambda$ and $E = pc$.
So $pc = hc/\lambda \implies \lambda = h/p$.
De Broglie proposed this holds for matter too.
$\lambda = \frac{h}{mv} = \frac{h}{\sqrt{2mK}}$

related_concepts.name: Davisson-Germer Experiment
related_concepts.definition: Experiment that proved the wave nature of electrons via diffraction.

subject: Physics
title: Moseley's Law
description: X-ray frequency relation to Atomic Number.
derivation:
Based on Bohr model for X-ray transitions.
Energy $\Delta E \propto (Z_{eff})^2$.
Frequency $\nu \propto \Delta E \propto (Z-b)^2$.
Taking square root:
$\sqrt{\nu} \propto (Z-b)$

related_concepts.name: Screening Constant
related_concepts.definition: Constant $b$ that accounts for the repulsion from inner shell electrons.

subject: Physics
title: Nuclear Radius
description: Size of nucleus depends on Mass Number $A$.
derivation:
Nuclear density is roughly constant.
Volume $V \propto A$ (Mass Number).
$\frac{4}{3}\pi R^3 \propto A$.
$R^3 \propto A \implies R \propto A^{1/3}$.
$R = R_0 A^{1/3}$

related_concepts.name: Femtometer (Fermi)
related_concepts.definition: Unit of length $1 fm = 10^{-15} m$, typical scale of nuclei.

subject: Physics
title: Mass-Energy Equivalence
description: Energy released due to mass defect.
derivation:
Derived from Special Relativity.
Mass and energy are interchangeable.
When nucleons form a nucleus, mass decreases (Mass Defect $\Delta m$).
This lost mass is released as Binding Energy.

related_concepts.name: Mass Defect
related_concepts.definition: Difference between mass of constituent nucleons and the actual nucleus mass.

subject: Physics
title: Radioactive Decay Law
description: Exponential decay of active nuclei.
derivation:
Rate of decay is proportional to number of nuclei present.
$\frac{dN}{dt} = -\lambda N$.
$\frac{dN}{N} = -\lambda dt$.
Integrate from $N_0$ to $N$: $\ln(N/N_0) = -\lambda t$.
$N = N_0 e^{-\lambda t}$

related_concepts.name: Decay Constant
related_concepts.definition: Probability of decay per unit time for a nucleus ($\lambda$).

subject: Physics
title: Half-Life
description: Time for number of nuclei to reduce to half.
derivation:
Set $N = N_0 / 2$ in decay equation.
$N_0 / 2 = N_0 e^{-\lambda T_{1/2}}$.
$1/2 = e^{-\lambda T_{1/2}} \implies 2 = e^{\lambda T_{1/2}}$.
Take $\ln$: $\ln 2 = \lambda T_{1/2}$.
$T_{1/2} = \frac{0.693}{\lambda}$

related_concepts.name: Activity
related_concepts.definition: Number of decays per second (Becquerel).

subject: Physics
title: Average Life
description: Mean survival time of a nucleus.
derivation:
Sum of all life times divided by total nuclei.
$\tau = \frac{\int_0^\infty t |dN|}{\int |dN|} = \frac{\int_0^\infty t (\lambda N_0 e^{-\lambda t}) dt}{N_0}$.
Solving integral $\lambda \int t e^{-\lambda t} dt$ gives $1/\lambda$.
$\tau = 1.44 T_{1/2}$

related_concepts.name: Statistical Nature
related_concepts.definition: Radioactivity is random; impossible to predict when a specific nucleus will decay.

subject: Physics
title: Activity
description: Rate of decay.
derivation:
Defined as $A = -\frac{dN}{dt}$.
From decay law: $\frac{d}{dt}(N_0 e^{-\lambda t}) = -\lambda N_0 e^{-\lambda t}$.
$A = \lambda N$.
Also follows $A = A_0 e^{-\lambda t}$.

related_concepts.name: Curie (Ci)
related_concepts.definition: Older unit of activity ($1 Ci = 3.7 \times 10^{10} Bq$).

subject: Physics
title: Projectile Time of Flight
description: Total time in air.
derivation:
Vertical motion: $u_y = u \sin \theta, a_y = -g$.
At highest point, $v_y = 0$. Time to rise $t_{up}$.
$v_y = u_y - gt \implies 0 = u \sin \theta - g t_{up}$.
$t_{up} = \frac{u \sin \theta}{g}$.
Total time $T = 2 t_{up} = \frac{2u \sin \theta}{g}$

related_concepts.name: Independence of Motion
related_concepts.definition: Horizontal and vertical components of projectile motion are independent.

subject: Physics
title: Projectile Max Height
description: Max vertical displacement.
derivation:
Using kinematic equation $v^2 - u^2 = 2as$ for vertical motion.
At max height $v_y = 0$, $u_y = u \sin \theta$.
$0 - (u \sin \theta)^2 = 2(-g)H$.
$H = \frac{u^2 \sin^2 \theta}{2g}$

related_concepts.name: Launch Angle
related_concepts.definition: Height is maximum at $\theta = 90^\circ$.

subject: Physics
title: Projectile Range
description: Horizontal distance covered.
derivation:
Horizontal speed $u_x = u \cos \theta$ (constant).
$R = u_x \times T = (u \cos \theta) \times \frac{2u \sin \theta}{g}$.
$R = \frac{u^2 (2 \sin \theta \cos \theta)}{g}$.
Using $\sin 2\theta = 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta$:
$R = \frac{u^2 \sin 2\theta}{g}$

related_concepts.name: Max Range
related_concepts.definition: Occurs at $45^\circ$. Complementary angles ($\theta, 90-\theta$) give same range.

subject: Physics
title: Equation of Trajectory
description: Path of projectile.
derivation:
Eliminate $t$ from $x$ and $y$ equations.
$x = (u \cos \theta) t \implies t = \frac{x}{u \cos \theta}$.
$y = (u \sin \theta)t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2$.
Substitute $t$:
$y = x \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} - \frac{g}{2} (\frac{x}{u \cos \theta})^2$.
$y = x \tan \theta - \frac{gx^2}{2u^2 \cos^2 \theta}$

related_concepts.name: Parabola
related_concepts.definition: Geometric shape of the projectile path ($y = ax - bx^2$).

subject: Physics
title: Trajectory (Range Form)
description: Trajectory equation using Range.
derivation:
Start from $y = x \tan \theta - \frac{gx^2}{2u^2 \cos^2 \theta}$.
Factor out $x \tan \theta$:
$y = x \tan \theta [ 1 - \frac{gx}{2u^2 \cos^2 \theta \tan \theta} ]$.
Simplify fraction: $\frac{gx}{2u^2 \sin \theta \cos \theta} = \frac{x}{R}$.
$y = x \tan \theta (1 - x/R)$

related_concepts.name: Symmetric Path
related_concepts.definition: The trajectory is symmetric about the vertical line $x = R/2$.

subject: Physics
title: Relative Velocity
description: Velocity of A with respect to B.
derivation:
Position vector $\vec{r}_{AB} = \vec{r}_A - \vec{r}_B$.
Differentiating with respect to time:
$\frac{d\vec{r}_{AB}}{dt} = \frac{d\vec{r}_A}{dt} - \frac{d\vec{r}_B}{dt}$.
$\vec{v}_{AB} = \vec{v}_A - \vec{v}_B$

related_concepts.name: Frame of Reference
related_concepts.definition: The coordinate system from which motion is observed (B is the frame here).

subject: Physics
title: River-Boat (Min Dist)
description: Heading to cross directly opposite.
derivation:
To cancel river flow $v_r$, horizontal component of boat velocity must oppose it.
$v_{b,x} = v_b \sin \theta$.
Condition: $v_b \sin \theta = v_r$.
$\sin \theta = v_r / v_b$.
Only possible if boat speed > river speed.

related_concepts.name: Drift
related_concepts.definition: Distance moved downstream. For min distance, drift is zero.

subject: Physics
title: River-Boat (Min Time)
description: Heading to cross fastest.
derivation:
Time to cross $t = \frac{\text{width}}{v_y}$.
$v_y = v_b \cos \theta$ (where $\theta$ is angle with normal).
To minimize $t$, maximize denominator $\cos \theta$.
Max $\cos \theta = 1$ at $\theta = 0$.
Boat must head perpendicular to flow.
$t_{min} = d/v_b$

related_concepts.name: Resultant Velocity
related_concepts.definition: Vector sum of boat and river velocity ($\sqrt{v_b^2 + v_r^2}$).

subject: Physics
title: Work (Variable Force)
description: Area under Force-Displacement graph.
derivation:
For constant force $W = F \cdot s$.
For variable force, consider small displacement $d\vec{r}$ where $F$ is approx constant.
$dW = \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r}$.
Summing all contributions via integration:
$W = \int_{r_1}^{r_2} \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r}$

related_concepts.name: Dot Product
related_concepts.definition: Scalar product indicating work depends on component of force parallel to displacement.

subject: Physics
title: Work-Energy Theorem
description: Net work equals change in Kinetic Energy.
derivation:
Newton's 2nd Law: $F_{net} = ma = m v \frac{dv}{dx}$.
$W = \int F dx = \int (m v \frac{dv}{dx}) dx = \int_{v_i}^{v_f} m v dv$.
$W = m [\frac{v^2}{2}]_{v_i}^{v_f} = \frac{1}{2}mv_f^2 - \frac{1}{2}mv_i^2$.
$W_{net} = K_f - K_i$

related_concepts.name: Kinetic Energy
related_concepts.definition: Energy possessed by an object due to its motion ($K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$).

subject: Physics
title: Instantaneous Power
description: Rate of doing work.
derivation:
Power $P = \frac{dW}{dt}$.
$dW = \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r}$.
$P = \vec{F} \cdot \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}$.
Since $d\vec{r}/dt = \vec{v}$:
$P = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{v}$

related_concepts.name: Watt (W)
related_concepts.definition: SI unit of power ($1 J/s$). Horsepower ($1 HP = 746 W$).

subject: Physics
title: Coeff. of Restitution
description: Measure of elasticity of collision.
derivation:
Defined as ratio of relative speed after collision to relative speed before.
$v_{sep} = v_2 - v_1$ (Separation).
$v_{app} = u_1 - u_2$ (Approach).
Newton's Law of Impact states this ratio $e$ is constant for a material pair.

related_concepts.name: Elastic Collision
related_concepts.definition: Collision where Kinetic Energy is conserved ($e=1$).

related_concepts.name: Inelastic Collision
related_concepts.definition: Collision where KE is lost ($e < 1$). Perfectly inelastic ($e=0$) objects stick.

subject: Physics
title: Heat Conduction
description: Rate of heat flow.
derivation:
Fourier's Law of Conduction.
Heat current $H$ is proportional to Area $A$ and Temp gradient $-dT/dx$.
$H = -KA \frac{dT}{dx}$.
For steady state rod of length $l$: $-dT/dx = (T_1 - T_2)/l$.
$H = \frac{KA \Delta T}{l}$

related_concepts.name: Thermal Conductivity
related_concepts.definition: Material property $K$ indicating ability to conduct heat.

subject: Physics
title: Thermal Resistance
description: Analogy to electrical resistance.
derivation:
Compare heat flow equation to Ohm's Law $I = V/R$.
Heat Current $H = \frac{\Delta T}{l/KA}$.
Temperature Difference $\Delta T$ is analogous to Potential Diff $V$.
Therefore, $R_{th} = \frac{l}{KA}$.

related_concepts.name: Series Combination
related_concepts.definition: Resistances add up ($R_{eq} = R_1 + R_2$) when heat flows through slabs sequentially.

subject: Physics
title: Stefan-Boltzmann Law
description: Power radiated by a body.
derivation:
Empirical law derived by Stefan and Boltzmann.
Energy radiated per second per unit area of a black body is $\propto T^4$.
$P_{black} = \sigma A T^4$.
For gray body, multiply by emissivity $e$ ($0 < e < 1$).

related_concepts.name: Black Body
related_concepts.definition: Ideal absorber and emitter ($e=1$).

subject: Physics
title: Wien's Displacement Law
description: Peak wavelength vs Temperature.
derivation:
Observed from Black Body Radiation spectrum.
The wavelength $\lambda_m$ corresponding to max intensity shifts to lower values as $T$ increases.
$\lambda_m \propto 1/T$.
$b$ is Wien's constant.

related_concepts.name: Color of Stars
related_concepts.definition: Hotter stars appear blue (lower $\lambda$), cooler stars appear red.

subject: Physics
title: Newton's Law of Cooling
description: Cooling rate for small temp difference.
derivation:
Approximation of Stefan's Law for small $\Delta T$.
Rate of loss $R \propto (T^4 - T_s^4)$.
If $T = T_s + \Delta T$, then $T^4 \approx T_s^4 (1 + 4\Delta T/T_s)$.
$R \propto \Delta T \propto (T - T_s)$.
$\frac{dT}{dt} = -K(T - T_s)$

related_concepts.name: Exponential Decay
related_concepts.definition: Temperature excess decays exponentially with time.

subject: Physics
title: Mean Free Path
description: Avg distance between gas collisions.
derivation:
Volume swept by molecule of diameter $d$ in time $t$ is $\pi d^2 (vt)$.
Number of collisions $N = n \times \text{Volume} = n \pi d^2 v t$.
Distance traveled $S = vt$.
Mean Path $\lambda = S/N = \frac{vt}{n \pi d^2 vt} = \frac{1}{\pi d^2 n}$.
Factor $\sqrt{2}$ accounts for relative motion of targets.

related_concepts.name: Number Density
related_concepts.definition: $n = N/V$, number of molecules per unit volume.

subject: Physics
title: Pressure of Ideal Gas
description: Kinetic theory result.
derivation:
Force from particle collision $F = \Delta p / \Delta t = 2mv_x / (2L/v_x) = mv_x^2/L$.
Pressure $P = F/A = \sum (mv_x^2/L) / L^2 = \frac{m}{L^3} \sum v_x^2$.
Using $v^2 = v_x^2 + v_y^2 + v_z^2 = 3\bar{v_x^2}$ (Isotropy).
$P = \frac{1}{3} \frac{Nm}{V} v_{rms}^2 = \frac{1}{3} \rho v_{rms}^2$

related_concepts.name: RMS Speed
related_concepts.definition: Root Mean Square speed, directly related to temperature ($v_{rms} \propto \sqrt{T}$).

subject: Physics
title: Internal Energy
description: Energy of Ideal Gas.
derivation:
From Equipartition Theorem.
Energy per degree of freedom is $\frac{1}{2}kT$.
Total energy for $N$ molecules with $f$ degrees:
$U = N \times f \times \frac{1}{2}kT = \frac{f}{2} (Nk) T$.
Since $Nk = nR$:
$U = \frac{f}{2} nRT$

related_concepts.name: Degrees of Freedom
related_concepts.definition: Number of independent ways a molecule can possess energy (3 trans, 2 rot...).

subject: Physics
title: Linear Expansion
description: Thermal expansion of solids.
derivation:
Experimental observation for small $\Delta T$.
Change in length is proportional to original length and temp change.
$\Delta L \propto L$ and $\Delta L \propto \Delta T$.
